column1: The 600 journalists embedded with American troops in Iraq will be threatened by the same fire as the troops they are covering.
column2: American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: This story is going to be told from a U.S. point of view.
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-10" type="COUNTRY"

column1: We are American reporters, the ones with the troops." (on camera): Now, none of this means journalists will ignore unsettling news: military setbacks, lack of supplies, the infliction of civilian casualties.
column2: American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" type="COUNTRY"

column1: But whether in the old Soviet Union or Nazi Germany or South Africa or Iraq , respect for the facts does not require a reporter to throw his values over the side.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",South Africa PLACE country="ZA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18714703" id="Pl-30" latLong="30.000°S 26.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Soviet Union PLACE country="OTHER" form="NAM" id="Pl-28" type="COUNTRY",Germany PLACE country="DE" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18224345" id="Pl-29" latLong="51.500°N 10.500°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Jeff Greenfield, CNN, New York . (END VIDEOTAPE) WOODRUFF And tonight on "LARRY KING LIVE," Al-Jazeera correspondent Omar Al Issawi will talk to Larry about the death of his colleague and the continuing plight of journalists in a war zone.
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-31" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: Just now, we want to show you scenes from Andrews Air Force Base just moments ago, President Bush returning to the United States from his summit in Northern Ireland in Belfast with British Prime Minister Tony Blair, the president back on American soil after a quick two-day trip, less than two-day trip to Belfast , he and the prime minister discussing, of course, the war in Iraq , what happens after, as well as the peace process in the Middle East , and restarting the peace process in Northern Ireland .
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-32" type="COUNTRY",American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" type="COUNTRY",British PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-35" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Belfast PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17410393" id="Pl-36" latLong="54.583°N 5.933°W" state="NIR" type="PPLA",Northern Ireland PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17395725" id="Pl-37" latLong="54.500°N 6.500°W" nonLocUse="true" state="NIR" type="CIVIL",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Still ahead: How is the world reacting to the war in Iraq ?
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: U.S.  Forces Hunt for Last of Saddam's Loyal Fighters
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: You are looking at live pictures of the White House where President Bush watched some of the television coverage of events in Baghdad today.
column2: ,Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="BG" type="PPLC"

column1: Separately, Vice President Cheney shared his thoughts in a speech in New Orleans .
column2: ,New Orleans PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1630985" id="Pl-26" latLong="29.954°N 90.075°W" state="LA" type="PPL"

column1: With me now for more on all this, CNN's senior White House correspondent John King.
John, they have to be happy there.
JOHN KING, CNN SNR.
WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT Judy, they are.

Behind the scenes privately here you get a palpable sense of vindication, although publicly caution is the watchword here, administration officials from the vice president on down saying the war is not over yet.
Some of the toughest fighting could still be ahead.
Mostly they believe in those northern Iraq areas Brent Sadler was just talking about before the break.
column2: ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: But they do believe the pictures out of Baghdad today, on the one hand, send as powerful a message as you can send to the people in the Arab world who have criticized this war.
column2: ,Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="BG" type="PPLC"

column1: People in Baghdad celebrating.
column2: ,Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="BG" type="PPLC"

column1: U.S. troops assisting in pulling down that statue of Saddam Hussein.
column2: ,U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-3" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Across the Arab world, the administration hopes to send a signal that the United States is there to help the Iraqi people regain control of their own country , as a liberty, not as any imperial or occupying force.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-6" type="COUNTRY", ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",country PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-20" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-23" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Of course, at the same time, though, the White House worries that the American people might see these pictures and think the war is over.
column2: ,American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Defense Secretary Rumsfeld and Vice President Cheney among those saying the toughest fighting might still lie ahead, still unanswered questions about the whereabouts of Saddam Hussein and other key members of the Iraqi leadership.
column2: ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-23" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The vice president made that argument today.
But even as he sounds that note of caution, you do sense a little tiny bit of we told you so.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DICK CHENEY, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES Bottom line, with less than half of the ground forces and two-thirds of the air assets used 12 years ago in Desert Storm, Secretary Rumsfeld and General Franks have achieved a far more difficult objective.
column2: ,UNITED STATES PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Yet until this war is fully won, we cannot be overconfident in our position.
And we must not underestimate the desperation of whatever forces remain loyal to the dictator.

(END VIDEO CLIP) KING We will not hear from the president today, we are told, but before the week is out and perhaps as early as tomorrow officials say the president is likely to offer his thoughts on the challenges just ahead.
So, again, behind the scenes, a sense of vindication, but also a cautious attitude because of the fighting still to come.
I have to tell you, though, Judy, the CIA Director George Tenet walked out of the White House a short time ago with a giant smile on his face.
I cannot recall a moment since September 11, 2001 and those tragic events when we have seen the CIA director look so happy.
WOODRUFF Well, John, given all that you've said, we know that there's an American retired general waiting in Kuwait .
column2: ,American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-27" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: But in addition to that, what steps are they already taking at the White House to plan for a post-Saddam Hussein government in Iraq ?
column2: ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: KING They are planning to accelerate that planning process.
Jay Garner the retired general will go into Iraq soon with his troops soon.
column2: ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: I say troops.
They are civilians from the U.S. government.
column2: ,U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-3" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: That will take place soon.
They are awaiting for word from the Pentagon that it believes the security environment is secure enough for that to happen.
And beginning as early as next week, there will be a series of town meetings, if you will.
The invitations will be issued by General Tommy Franks.

They are trying to identify Iraqis from within the country , as well as Iraqi dissidents and exiles, the diaspora they call it here at the White House , who will be part of a planning process to begin the process -- they say it could takes weeks or more -- of selecting who should be part of that interim Iraqi authority.
column2: ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",country PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-20" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-23" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Now, we know, one person who will be invited is planning process, those planning meetings, is Ahmed Chalabi.
He is the leader of the Iraqi National Congress.
column2: ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-23" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He is known to be a favorite of Vice President Dick Cheney, of Defense Secretary Rumsfeld and Secretary Rumsfeld's top deputy, Paul Wolfowitz.
He will be involved in the planning and in those meetings.

But I also should report that there is a sense of annoyance here at the White House , even among some of Mr. Chalabi's top supporters, that, since returning to Iraq in recent days, he has complained frequently, including on our air earlier today, that the United States is moving too slowly to get in the reconstruction efforts, to restore electricity and restore water.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-6" type="COUNTRY", ,Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Over at the Pentagon today, Defense Secretary Rumsfeld, again, a supporter of Mr. Chalabi, said that, in his view, services were already at their prewar levels.
And Mr. Rumsfeld went on to say, Secretary Rumsfeld went on to say, there is still a war going on, still quite a dangerous situation -- Judy.
WOODRUFF Yes, we caught some of that irritation in his choice.
All right, John King, our senior White House correspondent, thank you.
Still to come: warfare amid the celebrations in Baghdad .
column2: ,Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="BG" type="PPLC"

column1: As Iraqis poured into the streets to mark their apparent new freedom, American troops come under fire from a different area.
column2: ,American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-24" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-23" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: CNN's Martin Savidge will show us what they came up against at Baghdad University . (NEWS BREAK)
column2: ,Baghdad University PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-14" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="BG" type="PPLC",Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="BG" type="PPLC"

column1: U.S.  Forces Hunt for Last of Saddam's Loyal Fighters
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The United States Navy and Coast Guard crews are providing port security in the Persian Gulf during the Iraq war.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: And one group of sailors is getting letters from elementary school children in North Carolina .
column2: North Carolina PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1028616" id="Pl-9" latLong="35.501°N 80.001°W" state="NC" type="CIVIL"

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) DARYN KAGAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over) It started as a story on port security, how U.S. Navy and Coast Guard reserves are keeping ships safe from attack in Kuwait and Iraq . (on camera): The mission of these units is to protect these ports. (voice-over): But among the boats, guns, radar, sonar and communications, we found a secret weapon posted on the side of the tent that serves as the command center: letters from second-graders.
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-3" type="COUNTRY",Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-17" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: MIKE ROBERTS, U.S. NAVY "Dear brave friend.
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-3" type="COUNTRY"

column1: You are keeping the United States of America safe.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY",United States of America PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" type="COUNTRY"

column1: My brother is in Kuwait .
column2: Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-17" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: ROBERTS My sister is a grammar school teacher in Clayton , North Carolina .
column2: North Carolina PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1028616" id="Pl-9" latLong="35.501°N 80.001°W" state="NC" type="CIVIL",Clayton PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1020689" id="Pl-10" latLong="35.651°N 78.457°W" state="NC" type="PPL"

column1: Back in North Carolina , the Riverwood Elementary second-graders are working on the next batch.
column2: North Carolina PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1028616" id="Pl-9" latLong="35.501°N 80.001°W" state="NC" type="CIVIL"

column1: Hope you're doing well in North Carolina .
column2: North Carolina PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1028616" id="Pl-9" latLong="35.501°N 80.001°W" state="NC" type="CIVIL"

column1: Daryn Kagan, CNN, Kuwait . (END VIDEOTAPE) WOODRUFF Those letters important at both ends.
column2: Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-17" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: I'm Judy Woodruff in Washington .
column2: Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:532871" id="Pl-20" latLong="38.895°N 77.037°W" state="DC" type="PPLC"

column1: Saddam Hussein is Losing Grip on Northern Cities in Iraq
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-3" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: WOODRUFF Yesterday, there were scenes of jubilation in Baghdad , today, a suicide bombing and firefighters, grim reminders that, as U.S. Central Command put it, Baghdad is still an ugly place.
column2: Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-8" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC",U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-2" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",place PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-83" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: CNN's John Irvine has this profile of a city literally teetering on a razor's edge.
column2: city PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-10" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC"

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) JOHN IRVINE, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over) Getting acquainted, very deliberately, the U.S. Marines are trying to strike up a rapport with the people who are now their responsibility.
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-2" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: But there are still problems bringing control to Baghdad , particularly at nighttime.
column2: Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-8" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC"

column1: In the pitch black of a city without power, these soldiers manning a roadblock became nervous.
column2: city PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-10" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC",roadblock PLACE country="IE" form="NOM" id="Pl-77" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: In parts of Baghdad that the Americans haven't yet reached, there has been looting.
column2: Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-8" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC"

column1: This man took the horse from a stable at the home of Uday Hussein, Saddam's eldest son.
column2: home PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-88" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: We found the house , a large, gaudy structure , a place that just a few days ago people didn't even look at for fear of their lives.
column2: structure PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-80" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC",house PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-82" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC",place PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-83" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: This indeed was one of Uday's homes.
column2: home PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-88" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: Here, the ruling family could look out over the Tigris .
column2: Tigris PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16895173" id="Pl-11" latLong="31.000°N 47.417°E" type="WATER"

column1: People have wasted no time clearing the house and wrecking what couldn't be easily taken. (on camera): They haven't quite worked out just how to reach this will chandelier yet.
column2: house PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-82" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: But, other than that, they have stripped this place bare in less than 24 hours.
column2: place PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-83" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: Call it plunder, if you will, or perhaps payback. (voice-over): These Iraqis were rifling a home of a senior member of the Mukhabarat, Saddam's dreaded secret police.
column2: home PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-88" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: In the basement , we found burning archives and evidence of electronic surveillance.
column2: basement PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-96" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: This had been a nerve center for spying, a place from where the bully boys kept tabs to keep control. (on camera): We're now in the bowels of a secret police monitoring station . Look at all this gadgetry, quite sinister really, part of the apparatus of Big Brother. (voice-over): These people are stealing from a shopping center .
column2: shopping center PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-98" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC",place PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" id="Pl-83" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC"

column1: These thieves are trying to flee the German Embassy , having been shot at by a guard.
column2: Embassy PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" id="Pl-99" state="IQ-BG" type="FAC",German PLACE country="DE" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18224345" id="Pl-12" latLong="51.500°N 10.500°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: John Irvine, ITV News, Baghdad . (END VIDEOTAPE)
column2: Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-8" latLong="33.339°N 44.394°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC"

column1: Saddam Hussein is Losing Grip on Northern Cities in Iraq
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-1" latLong="33.000Â°N 44.000Â°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Well, Laith Kubba is an Iraqi exile who has family members in Iraq .
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-20" latLong="33.000Â°N 44.000Â°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-19" latLong="33.000Â°N 44.000Â°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He is also the president of a group of Iraqi exiles, a group called the Iraq National Group.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-20" latLong="33.000Â°N 44.000Â°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-19" latLong="33.000Â°N 44.000Â°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He joins us now from London to talk about rebuilding his country .
column2: London PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17398111" id="Pl-29" latLong="51.500Â°N 0.117Â°W" state="GB-ENG" type="PPLC",country PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-23" latLong="33.000Â°N 44.000Â°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Mr. Kubba, first of all, your thoughts as you've watched these scenes of Baghdad , the Saddam Hussein regime falling in the last day?
column2: Baghdad PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16896419" id="Pl-28" latLong="33.339Â°N 44.394Â°E" state="IQ-BG" type="PPLC"

column1: LAITH KUBBA, PRESIDENT, IRAQI NATIONAL GROUP It is a huge sigh of relief, because it could have been much worse and Baghdad could have been a war theater with more destruction to property.

column1: And I think all plans must be anchored there in Iraq in its reality.

column1: KUBBA There are different groups who have advantage over others in different parts of the country . Unfortunately, we do not have a national group that can appeal to Iraqis as Iraqis within a credible voice.This needs to be constructed, maybe through a conference to be held in Baghdad , where representatives from provinces all over Iraq need to participate, as well as political groups.

column1: Interview With Donald Rumsfeld; Lugar, Dodd Talk About Post-War Iraq  ;
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-3" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: We return now to my interview earlier today with the United States defense secretary, Donald Rumsfeld.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" type="COUNTRY"

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) BLITZER I know during the war, before the war, you were very concerned about the position of the Syrian government, cooperating with Iraqis, having an open border, if you will.
column2: Syria PLACE country="SY" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17451884" id="Pl-9" latLong="35.000°N 38.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-2" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Syrian PLACE country="SY" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17451884" id="Pl-8" latLong="35.000°N 38.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER But right now you're open-minded as far as Syria on whether they will crack down on terrorism, take some of the other steps that you want them to take?
column2: Syria PLACE country="SY" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17451884" id="Pl-9" latLong="35.000°N 38.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER The secretary of state has written you a letter expressing, apparently, some concern about the length that the prisoners are going to be spending, those detained at the U.S. Naval base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba , about 600 or so of them.
column2: Cuba PLACE country="CU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18380782" id="Pl-14" latLong="21.500°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY",U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-6" type="COUNTRY",Guantanamo Bay PLACE country="CU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18375476" id="Pl-11" latLong="20.003°N 75.133°W" type="WATER"

column1: There are a number of countries, and the Department of State has the responsibility of dealing with those countries, that have foreign nationals in Gitmo , in Guantanamo Bay , Cuba , being detained, and those countries, understandably, would like to know when they could have those people.So the inter-agency process takes a great deal of time.
column2: Cuba PLACE country="CU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18380782" id="Pl-14" latLong="21.500°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Gitmo PLACE country="CU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18375476" id="Pl-12" latLong="20.003°N 75.133°W" type="WATER",Guantanamo Bay PLACE country="CU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18375476" id="Pl-11" latLong="20.003°N 75.133°W" type="WATER"

column1: I remember covering General Schwarzkopf, the parades in Washington and New York after the first Gulf War.
column2: Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:532871" id="Pl-16" latLong="38.895°N 77.037°W" state="DC" type="PPLC",New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-18" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: Do you want the troops to be honored in that way when they come back, to have parades in New York , Washington , elsewhere?
column2: Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:532871" id="Pl-16" latLong="38.895°N 77.037°W" state="DC" type="PPLC",New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-18" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: And General Franks and his team have done just a superb job for our country and for the world, and indeed for the Iraqi people, who have been liberated.
column2: country PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-7" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-2" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In the case of 1991, the task was to go in and get them out of Kuwait , and they did it, and they were properly greeted coming back to the United States .
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" type="COUNTRY",Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-20" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER One final question on North Korea .
column2: North Korea PLACE country="KP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19818415" id="Pl-21" latLong="40.000°N 127.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: If the North Koreans pursue their nuclear weapons ambitions.
column2: North Korea PLACE country="KP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19818415" id="Pl-21" latLong="40.000°N 127.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Interview With Donald Rumsfeld; Lugar, Dodd Talk About Post-War Iraq  ;
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-1" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER President Bush aboard the USS Abraham Lincoln on Thursday, formally declaring the successful accomplishment of the military mission in Iraq .
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Joining us now are two key members of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-7" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In his home state of Indiana , the committee's chairman, Republican Senator Richard Lugar.
column2: Indiana PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:449508" id="Pl-9" latLong="40.000°N 86.250°W" state="US-IN" type="CIVIL"

column1: And here in Washington , Democratic Senator Christopher Dodd of Connecticut . Senators, welcome back to LATE EDITION.
column2: Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:532871" id="Pl-10" latLong="38.895°N 77.037°W" state="US-DC" type="PPL",Connecticut PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780780" id="Pl-11" latLong="41.667°N 72.667°W" state="US-CT" type="CIVIL"

column1: Are you among those who are beginning to conclude that, when all the dust settles, the U.S. may not find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq ?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: SEN. RICHARD LUGAR (R), INDIANA No, I concur with Secretary Powell, Secretary Rumsfeld, the president, that weapons of mass destruction are there, and likewise, that we will be led to them by people knowledgeable in the country as to where they are.
column2: country PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-17" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",INDIANA PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:449508" id="Pl-16" latLong="40.000°N 86.250°W" state="US-IN" type="CIVIL"

column1: And that, I think, we have to be working with these people who are in the business to make sure they don't re-enter the business, much as we did with Russian scientists under the Nunn-Lugar program.
column2: Russian PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-18" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: SEN. CHRISTOPHER DODD (D), CONNECTICUT I have no evidence to the contrary.
column2: CONNECTICUT PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780780" id="Pl-19" latLong="41.667°N 72.667°W" state="US-CT" type="CIVIL"

column1: There's no doubt about that at all, both in Iran and against the Kurdish population.
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-20" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: So, whether or not they find them in the exact form that many would assume they would be the case -- possibly some got out of the country.
column2: country PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-17" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He clearly was on the track to acquire a nuclear capacity, and the world is a safer place today because he's not ruling Iraq .
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER Will the U.S. lose creditability, Mr. Chairman, if, if the U.S. finds no hard evidence, no so-called smoking gun?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY"

column1: LUGAR No, we have full credibility in Iraq .
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: We've prosecuted with the alliance a successful liberation of the Iraqi people, and we have clearly caused Saddam to destroy weapons of mass destruction, or at least to suppress evidence of them.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-6" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER Senator Dodd, how important is it for the U.S. to conclusively learn what happened to Saddam Hussein?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Interview With Donald Rumsfeld; Lugar, Dodd Talk About Post-War Iraq  ;
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER What about the length of the U.S. military presence in Iraq , Senator Lugar?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-4" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: How long do you anticipate large numbers of U.S. troops will remain there?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: BLITZER And what about you, Senator Dodd, not only the length of time, but the cost to U.S. taxpayers?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-9" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Have you been given any ballpark estimate what this is going to cost the United States ?
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-11" type="COUNTRY"

column1: And clearly the responsibility is going to fall principally on the United States .
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-11" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Now, I would hope that sooner rather than later we could see a civilian government emerge in Iraq , a democratically elected one, that there'd be more cooperation from the international community, on both the peacekeeping side as well as the political restructuring that's necessary in Iraq .
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-4" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: And secondarily, what about countries like France , Germany , and Russia , which opposed the Bush administration's war plans, do you want them shut out?
column2: France PLACE country="FR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18572019" id="Pl-12" latLong="46.000°N 2.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Russia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-14" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Germany PLACE country="DE" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18224345" id="Pl-13" latLong="51.500°N 10.500°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: And I do hope the United Nations will play a vital role in Iraq , whether it be in peacekeeping or various other ways, and I hope that that will occur soon.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-4" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Interview With Howard Dean; Will U.S.  Catch Saddam Hussein?
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: I will say that it is a huge problem, and you've got hundreds of thousands, millions of these containers, cargo containers, coming into the country everyday, Lord only knows where from.
column2: country PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" type="COUNTRY"

column1: I mean, some of these problems are so staggering -- how do you deal with the border with Mexico ?
column2: Mexico PLACE country="MX" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18316662" id="Pl-2" latLong="23.000°N 102.000°W" mod="BORDER" type="COUNTRY"

column1: How do you deal with the border with Canada , where you in -- in many case, you can just walk across a field in Minnesota .
column2: Canada PLACE country="CA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19437937" id="Pl-3" latLong="60.000°N 96.000°W" mod="BORDER" type="COUNTRY"

column1: You've got supposedly, according to some Canadian officials, 50 al Qaeda operatives that they believe are there.
column2: Canadian PLACE country="CA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19437937" id="Pl-4" latLong="60.000°N 96.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: This is a huge country and we have porous borders and our ports are vulnerable.
column2: country PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" type="COUNTRY"

column1: KING Spokane , Washington , as we go to some calls.
column2: Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-6" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL",Spokane PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1513683" id="Pl-7" latLong="47.659°N 117.425°W" state="WA" type="PPL"

column1: HUTCHISON We know he has chemical weapons because he used them on his own people up in the north against the Kurds.
column2: north PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-8" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" mod="N" type="COUNTRY"

column1: So, it has been very difficult for our people to get the information that we need to find Saddam Hussein and show the Iraqi people that this man is gone, and they will be able to have a life if they will work with us give themselves a chance at freedom.
column2: Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-9" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: KING Marina , California , hello.
column2: California PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780778" id="Pl-10" latLong="37.250°N 119.750°W" state="CA" type="CIVIL",Marina PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1660061" id="Pl-11" latLong="36.684°N 121.801°W" state="CA" type="PPL"

column1: Robin Wright of the " Los Angeles Times." Senator Bob Graham, a candidate for his parties nomination.
column2: Los Angeles PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1663328" id="Pl-12" latLong="34.052°N 118.243°W" state="CA" type="PPL"

column1: And Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas .
column2: Texas PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780801" id="Pl-13" latLong="31.250°N 99.250°W" state="TX" type="CIVIL"

column1: Westwood , California , with Ronald Reagan -- hello.
column2: California PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780778" id="Pl-1" latLong="37.250°N 119.750°W" state="CA" type="CIVIL",Westwood PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1661156" id="Pl-2" latLong="40.306°N 121.005°W" state="CA" type="PPL"

column1: You recently made a visit to Palmdale to see it.
column2: Palmdale PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1653769" id="Pl-3" latLong="34.579°N 118.116°W" state="CA" type="PPL"

column1: REAGAN Well, yes, because, you know, that vested aristocracy there, all of those Politburo members and so forth, they're frightened that a change in the system is going to take away their perquisites, just as he closed down their private stores where they could go in without waiting on line and they could choose from any one of a half a dozen meats, where the Russian citizens had to stand hours in line and there would only be one kind of meat when they did get in the store.
column2: Russian PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-4" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Nicholas Lemann has worked first for "The Atlantic Monthly" and now "The New Yorker," covering everything from politics to education to poverty and has written four books in the process.
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-2" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: But now he is taking on a new job at one of the nation 's most prestigious universities, dean of Columbia's Journalism School.
column2: nation PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Nick Lemann joins us now from New York . Welcome.
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-2" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: I myself started my career at age 17 at an alternative paper, so I'm a beneficiary of the lack of credentials, but I do think that at a great university like Columbia, we're the only Ivy League graduate-only journalism school, you can draw on the extraordinary riches of the university, of New York City , of the media industry that's pretty much headquartered here, and of the faculty and alumni of this school and really provide something special for the people who go there.
column2: New York City PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-3" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL",New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-2" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: Most recently "The Atlantic Monthly" and "The New Yorker."
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-2" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL"

column1: Second of all, just on a small point, I believe "The New Yorker" now has a bigger circulation than "The Washington Post" so, you know, who is calling who a small circulation publication?
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-2" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL",Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:532871" id="Pl-4" latLong="38.895°N 77.037°W" state="DC" type="PPL"

column1: Will U.S.  Send Troops Into Liberia  ?; Hussein Releases New Audiotape;
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: But first, we're going to go to outside Moscow , to our correspondent Jill Dougherty, who is covering explosions at a rock concert -- Jill.
column2: Moscow PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17039439" id="Pl-4" latLong="55.752°N 37.616°E" state="MOS" type="PPLC"

column1: JILL DOUGHERTY, CNN MOSCOW BUREAU CHIEF Yes.
column2: MOSCOW PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17039439" id="Pl-3" latLong="55.752°N 37.616°E" state="MOS" type="PPLC"

column1: You know, we're just down the street from where that happened.
column2: street PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-49" type="FAC"

column1: It's right outside a big air base called Tushino , where a concert, a rock concert called Wings was taking place.
column2: Tushino PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-39" type="FAC",base PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-38" type="FAC"

column1: There were about 20,000 people inside that stadium .
column2: stadium PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-47" type="FAC"

column1: And luckily, if you can say it's lucky, the two explosions took place outside of the stadium , apparently at the entrance .
column2: stadium PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-47" type="FAC"

column1: In fact, we're just close to that entrance a few minutes ago, where two female suicide bombers tried to get into the stadium .
column2: stadium PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-47" type="FAC"

column1: You can still see, in fact, and I was down there as I said just a minute ago, you can still see two bodies lying on the street , and police are obviously taking forensic evidence and trying to figure out precisely how it happened, but I could say that it would appear to fit that scenario of having the two females suicide bombers.
column2: street PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-49" type="FAC"

column1: The people who were inside the stadium really did not know what was going on.
column2: stadium PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-47" type="FAC"

column1: But outside the stadium , the latest reports, 18 people killed, and many wounded, although we don't have a final figure on that.
column2: stadium PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-47" type="FAC"

column1: DOUGHERTY Not that we have heard, although you would have to say that this really does have the fingerprint of Chechen terrorists.
column2: Chechen PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17103517" id="Pl-7" latLong="43.300°N 45.700°E" state="CE" type="CIVIL"

column1: After all, just in the past month or so, we have had a couple of incidents in Chechnya and the region in the south of Russia of females suicide bombers with explosives strapped to their waist, blowing themselves up, and killing people besides.
column2: Chechnya PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17103517" id="Pl-9" latLong="43.300°N 45.700°E" state="CE" type="CIVIL",Russia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-10" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" mod="S" type="COUNTRY"

column1: And also, police are saying that they found the passport of one of the women, a girl, 20 years old, who does have a name that is Chechen .
column2: Chechen PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17103517" id="Pl-7" latLong="43.300°N 45.700°E" state="CE" type="CIVIL"

column1: Do the Russian people support his moves on the security issues against the Chechens?
column2: Russian PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-11" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Chechen PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17103517" id="Pl-7" latLong="43.300°N 45.700°E" state="CE" type="CIVIL",Russia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-10" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" mod="S" type="COUNTRY"

column1: DOUGHERTY Well, if they're cracking down on security in Moscow , you would have to say that people do support that by and large, because they're scared.
column2: Moscow PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17039439" id="Pl-4" latLong="55.752°N 37.616°E" state="MOS" type="PPLC"

column1: Remember last October, you had the theater hostage crisis, and people want security.
column2: theater PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" id="Pl-48" predicative="true" type="FAC"

column1: Now, if you're talking about the crackdowns in Chechnya , there you have to say that it's kind of a mixed bag.
column2: Chechnya PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17103517" id="Pl-9" latLong="43.300°N 45.700°E" state="CE" type="CIVIL"

column1: Many people think they ought to simply get rid of the terrorists, do whatever they can and get tough, but there are other people who believe that it's precisely that type of get tough and round them up type of approach that's spurring on the violence and -- by the Chechens.

column1: Maybe he tried to invest in his paper, maybe he believed sincerely in his admiration for the poor innocent dead guy and his ability of earning PhDs, but using a big car and living in a big house are signs for the masses that the man is an invaluable and irreplaceable leader.

column1: 2004-11-08T19:42:06 The interim government declared a state of emergency in Iraq excluding the Kurdish region for 60 days, according to the National Security Law introduced last August which states that emergency laws can be declared in the country for a period no more than 60 days provided a serious threat against Iraqi national security is recognised by the interim government.

column1: Mon, 28 Feb 2005 19:19:14 -0800 Sock Painting Party Howdy PR, We are going to be having a sock painting party at my house instead of the normal meeting at St. Mary's.
It is going to be Wednesday from 5 till 10.
Come and go as you need to.
We need lots and lots of help because there are tons of socks to do.
We have already made one pair and they look awesome!
Everyone from the campaign in invited!
If you can please bring... junky clothes (wear shorts), scissors, blowdryers, duck tape and plastic bags.

The directions to my house are... - Start on Texas Ave. and head away from Bryan - Go down Texas Ave. until you come to South West Parkway - Take right on SW Parkway - Go down SW Parkway until you come to Welsh (stoplight) - Take right on Welsh - The apartment complex is called Renaissance Park and is on the immediate left - Go into second entrance of the complex on left (mailbox should be on right side) - Park anywhere - I am in building 24 apartment #241 - We will possibly be out back around pool if no one answers door

column1: 2005-02-17T21:15:00 Has the EU once again lost its mind?

The one industry in which Europe incontrovertibly beats the US is their aviation industry , thanks mainly to the fact that their lawmakers have left the operation of the industry up to the people who own it, and left passenger's rights in the hands of choosy passengers.
column2: ,US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-2" type="COUNTRY"

column1: And now they're ready to 'fix' that with a new package of ill-advised rules completely changing the nature of airlines . Before, a potential customer could choose between a cosy, near-certain ride from an expensive company or a hustled, uncomfortable, and absurdly cheap one from a smaller competitor.
And now?
Not a chance.

column1: Thu, 20 Jan 2005 10:04:19 +0100 The Pain of Childbirth I have 2 girls already, nearly 8 and 4.5 yrs and I have always said I will NEVER forget the pain of childbirth.

Abby was a true water birth (3kg - normal) and with Fiona I was dragged out of the pool after the head crowned (gyno had written on my notes she was 4kg (large) and that she was not to be born in the water (long painful story!
) I can still remember though the pain I felt.
I am on the large side but I am so worried about how I'm going to cope with a natural childbirth without a pool (not available round here).
I've seen videos and heard of ladies who have "managed" their pain control.
How in Heavens name can you do that?
I've been there; I know what the pain feels like!!
Can anyone give me advice or let me know of any techniques which might be able to help?
Thanks in advance.
Anna Mc Dagny Thu, 20 Jan 2005 06:08:30 -0500 Re: The Pain of Childbirth If you don't have an institutional water birth available, have you considered just staying home?
Unassisted or midwife attended?
I understand hypnobirthing can be very helpful.
I am not pursuing it because I was able to go inside the pain to the good place without training, last time.
I have not been thinking much about the hard part of labor prior to getting so close.
Now I remember how intense it is.
I think I am still looking forward to it more than fearing it, but hey.
It's a really intense, vulnerable thing.
-- Dagny Welches Thu, 20 Jan 2005 15:52:49 GMT Re: The Pain of Childbirth If you go for a home birth you can rent a birthing pool.
I wouldn't necessaritly say that you will have a repeat labour!
My first labour I was 30 hours and had an epidural after 22 hours.
#2 I went in saying "give me the epidural asap-and never got to the state where I felt that I needed it.
Only had tens and gas-and-air.
So don't give up on the idea of a natural birth because last time was painful.

I think different people different labours are different, so just because one person says "I did *** and it didn't hurt a bit" doesn't mean that it will work for someone else, so going in with a set of suggestions, and being prepared to try them and see which is the best is probably the most helpful.
(Oh and "it didn't hurt a bit" is usually helped by mummy amnesia!!;-P) Debbie

Thu, 02 Dec 2004 16:48:31 -0500 waiver of extradition means what My girlfriend was on the run from probation in Fla when she got herself in trouble here in Az . which apparantly, true to her habits, she tried to avoid by not showing up for court.

column1: Time goes by, we meet etc etc she gets herself under the scrutiny of the police and into jail again. fla trouble 1999 she signed a waiver of extradition as part of her plea deal Az in trouble in 2001, fla is mentioned and she signs another waiver of extradition, posts bonds and skips (not far enough apparantly) Az troubles again in 2004, she serves 6 months , then the day before she is to be released to do 5 yrs probation her in az , fla shows up and takes her to fla faceing her original 1999 charges which are still open (she failed miserably at probation) I think they want to give her 3 years.

column1: Sat, 29 Jan 2005 22:25:56 -0500 Question regarding simple assault & battery My roommate was hospitalized in mid-November for lung surgery and spent several days on loads of pain medication.
On the fourth day of his stay, he was moved out of the ICU to the step-down unit , with a diagnosis of " ICU Psychosis secondary to narcotic administration" and post thoracostomy."
He was confused, because of the medication but was not aggressive or threatening in any manner.
I saw him each day and as soon as we spoke, he became oriented and was perfectly fine.
This was witnessed by both the nursing staff and his doctors.

During the early evening hours of his sixth hospital day, he got up, dressed, pulled his chest tube out and managed to get out of the hospital and across four lanes of busy evening traffic, to our apartment .
By the time he got to our home , he was very short of breath and there was a nurse and orderly who told me "he's crazy and just walked out."
I sat him down on the couch and talked to him, and asked him what had happened.
He said he'd asked for something for pain and they told hime he couldn't have anything.
Then the orderly was apparently rude to him, and that's when he got up and decided to come home.
A short time later, two police officers showed up and told me they had to take him back to the hospital .
He went back with the officers, gave them no problems at all.
I received a call from the shift supervisor who told me they'd replaced his chest tube, given him some pain medication and he was doing much better.
I told her to pass on the other shifts that if he became confused or upset to call me, and I'd talk to him, and get him settled down.
At 2:15 the next morning, I received a call from the night shift supervisor who told me my friend had been "verbally abusive and aggressive" and would I come over and talk to him.
So, I went over there, getting to his room right at 2:30.
There were two cops there and I asked what had happened.
My roommate was in bed, sound asleep, and had all of his clothes on.
A nurse said, "He beat two of us up.
The cops are here because we're pressing charges."
I've lived with this man 9 years and never in that time have I ever seen him be aggressive, violent or abusive in anyway.
I asked to speak to the two nurses whom he'd alledgedly hit and was told I couldn't do that.
An hour or so passed and the got my roommate out of bed, took his chest tube out and discharged him.
He was sent to another hospital with a psych unit until his psychosis resolved.
I was given copies of a citation for simple assault and battery, then went to the police station several days later to find out what other paperwork was available on this incident.
I was given a copy of a different citation, but with the identical information from the one I'd gotten the night of the incident.

The police report has the victim saying she was "choked to where she almost lost consciousness, struck in the face with a belt buckle and it had left large marks, and that he'd grabbed her breasts and left marks.
According to the police report, this woman never reported to the ER for verification of the injuries and no one else can verify exactly what happened to provoke this incident.
My roommate has no recollection of the time from the day before the incident happened until he woke up at the other hospital .
He was cited for simple assault and battery.
If there is no evidence, and that includes the belt buckle, how can the county prosecute this case.
? case.?
All of his belongings were returned to me upon his discharge, with the exception of the belt buckle.
The police do not have it and the hospital doesn't know what happened to it.
Also, I was looking at both citations, I didn't get to the hospital until 2:30 am, and the officer has the time of incident as being at 2:34 am.
Does anyone besides me see a problem with any of this?
What kind of recourse does my roommate have in all of this?

com Newave Communications ============================== ============================== ========== Mark A Tue, 01 Feb 2005 18:16:40 -0500 Re: Question regarding simple assault & battery Get a criminal defense lawyer (I don't say that very often on this newsgroup).
If your roommate cannot afford one, contact your roommate's parents about paying for one, or ask about getting a court appointed lawyer.

Tommy Franks and his field commanders face a big decision _ whether to rush into the city of 5 million where Hussein's regime has gathered its most-trusted forces or wait and see if the war can be won without paying the price of street-to-street urban fighting.

column1: Thousands of refugees have fled the city , apparently providing information to the British that has led to raids on military and Baath Party sites in the city . ``The key endgame may be whether the U.S. can parse out the key regime centers of power in Baghdad and attack them without having to fight into the city , or at least locate them well enough to atman of the Center for Strategic and International Studies said in his daily war report.

column1: But Michael O'Hanlon of the Brookings Institution in Washington said the apparent collapse of Republican Guard resistance could deprive Hussein of much of the wallop he was counting on in the city . ``If U.S. forces seriously degrade Iraq 's half-dozen Republican Guard divisions before that final battle, and only have to face perhaps 30,000 Special Republican Guard, fedayeen, and related personnel, the task will not be as hard as it might have been,'' he said.

column1: Sat, 19 Mar 2005 20:31:04 -0500 Can I get Security Clearence?
Or I am done forever.
Hi: I am in a dilemma.
I am a experienced Oracle DBA Unix Sys Adm and a Com Sci grad. from Carleton and have been out of work for about 6 months now.
I have a chance of getting a position but it requires enhanced security clearence.
Now, back in my high school days I was charged and convicted for assault (after I had just turned 18) for punching some bully.
And at that time I did'tn know what "conditional sentence" was as my lawyer provided by the court to me told me that if I pleaed guilty that's what I would get and "all this will end".
Additonally, he told me that I would'nt have a record (as this charge would disappear after 3 years).
This happened in 1998, and recently when I was asked to get a police report check for one of jobs I had applied for, I was told that I had a record.
So basically, now after 7 years I have located thsi bad news and possibly would ruin my chances of getting any decent job.
My question is (who may shed some light on this), can you pass Enhance Reliability Clearence in my position?
From my research it shows that I would have to apply for pardon with govt.
Or I can get my case reopened and see what my options are (as I was never guilty but I did what I did in self defense).
Can anyone advise me on this? (of course I plan to speak to a legal professional as well but looking for someone who may know if its possible to get security clearance in my situation).
Appreciate your time.
Thank you.
Trev B Sat, 19 Mar 2005 21:32:21 -0500 Re: Can I get Security Clearence?
Or I am done forever.
I'm no lawyer, but I think your only option would be to apply for a pardon.
The courts would not re-open your case as you had pleaded guilty to the charge, whether it was warranted or not.
May be different had you been found guilty and new evidence appeared to support your claim of innocence.
You're best to seek the advice of a lawyer, not others in this forum.
I think the The Law Society of Upper Canada provides a free 30 minute consultation with a barrister, though that may have changed.
I can tell you that a lawyer is not needed to apply for a pardon.
Trev B dav...@magma.ca Mon, 21 Mar 2005 01:13:37 -0500 Re: Can I get Security Clearence?
Or I am done forever.
A non property offense with limited possibility of personal gain helps.
The fact that the sentence was so recent does not. 50 50 at best but worth a shot.
The pardon services don't speed things up (currently 31 months total time from first form until pardon) irecr...@gmail.com 22 Mar 2005 12:43:16 -0800 Re: Can I get Security Clearence?
Or I am done forever.
I would say Joe has the best view of this situation.
I am an ACSO (Alternate Corporate Security Officer, big title, means I push more paper for the same pay!) and I am the go-to person for Federal Clearances.
I'll likely be able to get you a clearance but I will take some time(3-6 months is my guess). you will need a transcript of your conviction (opp-RCMP) and likely need fingerprints.
Reliability shoud be no problem but Secret is pretty much out of the question (not impossible just highly improbable) until your pardon.
Feel free to contact me.

column1: 30 Jan 2005 10:06:08 -0800 OT: Republican election standards Here on the left edge of the country , we have a unique perspective on election standards.
column2: country PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-34" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In Iraq , an election takes place in which one of the three major forces vying for control of the country opts out.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-6" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",country PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-34" type="COUNTRY"

column1: It is hailed as the greatest triumph of democracy since the defeat of Imperial Japan .
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-9" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In Washington State , our governor's race may be undecided for months to come.
column2: Washington State PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-18" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: Following the election and recount process exactly as outlined in our state constitution, the democratic candidate won by a margin of less than 200 votes.
column2: state PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-17" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: The same group of people who have said "even if some regions are too unsafe for people to go to the polls and even if large portions of the population will not recognize the legitimacy of the outcome, some election is better than no election, and it's a great day for democracy!"...........are suing to overthrow the results of the governor's election is Washington State because there were some "errors" in the process.
column2: Washington State PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-18" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: ) So the standards are: Any old process halfway resembling an election is just diddly dandy in Iraq , but we won't accept the results of a free and fair election in Washington State because there may have been a human error rate of 0.0000001 percent.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-6" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Washington State PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-18" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: In Washington State , the election has to be not only free and fair, but also "perfect".
column2: Washington State PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-18" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: (Of course, the Republicans would have thought the WA State election *was* perfect, had their candidate held the same 100 and some vote margin when all the smoke finally cleared).
column2: WA State PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-16" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: Bert Robbins Sun, 30 Jan 2005 13:52:34 -0500 Re: Republican election standards We have seen our state 's standards.
column2: state PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-17" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: The ones that are "opting" out are in one of three protected classes within Iraq .
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-6" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: This didn't happen in Washington State .
column2: Washington State PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780804" id="Pl-18" latLong="47.500°N 120.500°W" state="WA" type="CIVIL"

column1: Wasn't it King County that had "counted" more votes than registered voters.
column2: King County PLACE country="US" county="King County" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1532933" id="Pl-19" latLong="47.467°N 121.817°W" state="WA"

column1: Think about this objectively (forget the US is involved), if a foreign country invaded another and set up elections, wouldn't a reasonable person question the validity of the election results?
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-29" type="COUNTRY",country PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-34" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Even if you, John H, believe the US held impartial elections in Iraq , don't you think the rest of the world will find the results invalid, or least suspect?

column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-29" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Bert Robbins Sun, 30 Jan 2005 20:26:26 -0500 Re: OT: Republican election standards You have to start somewhere and this election is to get a legislative body to write a constitution for Iraq .

column1: The US soldiers were purposely kept well away from the polls during the time the polls were open.

column1: They were the outer of three concentric security rings, with the Iraqi police and Army occupying the closest two rings.

column1: Fischer will not be extradited from Iceland
column2: Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-1" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Thu, 24 Mar 2005 22:00:45 +0000 Fischer will not be extradited from Iceland According to: These treaties are at: (...): and (...) Article I (from the first .com URL above) states that extradition can only occur: So, since playing chess in Yugoslavia has never been against the law in Iceland , Fischer cannot be extradited to the US for having done this.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-20" type="COUNTRY",Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-11" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Article V states that: In short, if the US government dared to submit a request for Fischer's extradition, the Icelandic government would not be in breach of the treaty if it told the US government to stick its request up its arse.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-20" type="COUNTRY",Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-11" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Icelandic PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-9" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: (Note: I have not yet found anything on the 1972 treaty mentioned at: (...) but I think it may be a red herring since I don't understand how in 1972 a treaty between the US and Denmark could bind Iceland which by 1972 was an 'independent' and 'sovereign' country).
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-20" type="COUNTRY",Denmark PLACE country="DK" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17258977" id="Pl-21" latLong="56.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-11" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: However it is possible that US government gangsters might want to kidnap Fischer in Iceland and bundle him to the US base at Keflavik , so I hope he employs good security.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-20" type="COUNTRY",Keflavik PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17351701" id="Pl-25" latLong="64.017°N 22.567°W" state="2" type="PPLA",Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-11" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: (Mick Travis, 'If...', 1968) banana Thu, 24 Mar 2005 22:25:35 +0000 Re: Fischer will not be extradited from Iceland You have to laugh at how the ' New York Times' sneers at Iceland as ' Kentucky -sized' and 'windswept': Why don't they say what they mean, and call it a shitty little rock in the North Atlantic that doesn't even have its own army?
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-22" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL",Kentucky PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780786" id="Pl-23" latLong="37.500°N 85.250°W" predicative="true" state="KY" type="CIVIL",Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-11" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: They don't seem to be able to bring themselves to report the *truth*, namely that the Icelandic government has had the courage to support a man in his 60s whom the US criminal regime is persecuting and seeking to jail for up to 10 years for the 'crime' of playing chess thousands of miles away from US territory.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-20" type="COUNTRY",Iceland PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-11" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Icelandic PLACE country="IS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17352216" id="Pl-9" latLong="65.000°N 18.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Thu, 16 Dec 2004 15:47:26 GMT Turns out the August 2003 crisis was not a crisis Turns out the August 2003 crisis was not a crisis Everyone has heard the story: Beatriz Marinello was elected USCF President on August 11, 2003 in Los Angeles .
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Los Angeles PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1663328" id="Pl-2" latLong="34.052°N 118.243°W" state="US-CA" type="PPL"

column1: Immediately after she took office, she found out that the USCF had no money in the bank, zero.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The USCF did not even have the money to pay the guaranteed prizes at the just concluded US Open in Los Angeles . Therefore, on August 20, 2003, bravely Beatriz walked into the USCF Offices in New Windsor and immediately fired 17 staff members.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Los Angeles PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1663328" id="Pl-2" latLong="34.052°N 118.243°W" state="US-CA" type="PPL"

column1: Of course, it was just a pure coincidence that the 17 people Beatriz fired were the people she had grown to dislike during the year that she worked for the USCF in 1999-2000.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: It took six weeks before the USCF paid the guaranteed prizes the prize winners had won at the US Open.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The USCF did not have zero money in the bank.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The office accountant for the USCF had set up a separate bank account and had put the entry fees from the US Open into that account.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Perhaps the accountant was following a procedure followed by the USCF for scholastic tournaments.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: For this act of stupidity which had caused a grave crisis in the USCF, the accountant was immediately fired.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-5" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He was asked to wait until after the LA meeting was over before resigning.
column2: LA PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1663328" id="Pl-6" latLong="34.052°N 118.243°W" state="US-CA" type="PPL"

column1: We also had a buyer for the building at a prize much higher than it was eventually sold for and a commitment for 4% bank financing in Crossville .

column1: We're planning on going July 4th week -- what better time to be in Boston I figure :) Saturday, July 2nd - Fly from Austin , Tx to Boston and stay with friends living in Boston Sunday, July 3rd - Hang around Boston and stay with friends Monday, July 4th - Hang around Boston and stay with friends Tuesday, July 5th - Leave early and drive to Niagara Falls , NY - 467 miles - Stay in Niagara Falls Wednesday, July 6th - Leave from Niagara Falls and drive to Toronto , On - 85 miles - Drive back to Niagara Falls that evening - 85 miles - Stay in Niagara Falls Thursday, July 7th - Leave Niagara Falls and drive to Red Bank , NY - 435 miles - Stay in Red Bank for the night - We want to hit-up Jay and Silent Bob's Silent Stash Friday, July 8th - Drive back to Boston passing through New York -- do whatever -- 262 Miles from Red Banks to Boston but add whatever miles from New York - Stay the night with friends in Boston Saturday, July 9th - Fly back to Austin I figure staying in Red Bank , NJ , which isn't far from NYC , is cheaper then staying in the city . Plus while driving back north to Boston we can spend the day in NYC .

column1: I hear discussion along the lines that the United States was *wanting* to go to war with Japan , and had been trying to bring that about for years.

column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: I've read quite a few more rational works describing how the US was doing its best to avoid, or at the very least postpone, a war against Japan , mainly because FDR was trying to provoke Hitler to war and didn't need a distraction on another distant front. work? (stuff deleted) The thesis has been expounded by several conspiracy theorists, mainly the ones who expounded that FDR knew Pearl Harbor was about to be attacked, and let it happen.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",Pearl Harbor PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:364230" id="Pl-77" latLong="21.355°N 157.972°W" state="US-HI" type="WATER",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Pearl PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:364230" id="Pl-66" latLong="21.355°N 157.972°W" state="US-HI" type="WATER"

column1: One of their "proofs" was that the US carriers were out of port during the attack, and "everybody knew" carriers were the capital ship of the future.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY"

column1: However, the two carriers operating out of Pearl at the moment were sent West with light escort, on possibly intersecting routes with the IJN Kido Butai, which had far more carriers and a far heavier escort.
column2: Pearl PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:364230" id="Pl-66" latLong="21.355°N 157.972°W" state="US-HI" type="WATER"

column1: Even stranger, the USS Enterprise was scheduled to be at Pearl by Dec 6th, but got delayed by a storm.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",Pearl PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:364230" id="Pl-66" latLong="21.355°N 157.972°W" state="US-HI" type="WATER"

column1: Consequently, for the PH conspiracy theorists to believe that FDR kept the carriers out of harm's way, we not only have to grant FDR the full knowledge of Kido Butai's route of approach would not result in either USN carrier fleet getting caught in a hopeless battle, but that FDR could psychically manipulate the weather to prevent Halsey from sailing into Pearl and thus be ambushed.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",PH PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:364230" id="Pl-65" latLong="21.355°N 157.972°W" state="US-HI" type="WATER",Pearl PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:364230" id="Pl-66" latLong="21.355°N 157.972°W" state="US-HI" type="WATER"

column1: To make a very long story short, it is foolish to assume that the US wanted to go to war against Japan prior to 1941, considering the weight of evidence arguing against a US desire for war, and the overwhelming lack of evidence (not to mention rational thought) arguing for a US desire for war.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"
