column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Here's something I wrote as part of a larger article, some while ago: Wasn't Japan just defending herself when she attacked the US ?
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: This line of reasoning seems to derive from arguments that Japan was being "driven into a corner" by sanctions, and had no choice but to attack the US .
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Meiji Japan was driven to emulate what it thought the West was doing in every facet of society.
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: They had observed, for example, that the West was able to carve up China into "Spheres of Influence", and was able to do from great distances, while they, the Japanese, had had limited success in their previous attempts to dominate the Korean peninsula , much less China .
column2: Japanese PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-44" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY",China PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18099327" id="Pl-55" latLong="35.000°N 105.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: However, after World War I, Japan failed to recognize a fundamental shift in the attitudes of her former Imperial partners; they began a long, slow process of disengaging themselves from their former Imperial areas, from their colonies, in addition to outright stopping all expansions.
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Japan chose to read this as a sign that the West had lost its power and resolve, and that Japan was the rightful heir to Imperial mantle in Asia .
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: With the deaths of many of the idealistic leaders who had led Japan 's rise to international prominence, and the refusal of the US to intervene in Asian affairs, in addition to the Bolshevik revolution and the stripping of possessions from Germany , Britain found herself alone in dealing with an increasingly aggressive Japan in the area.
column2: Britain PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-75" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY",US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-17" type="COUNTRY",Germany PLACE country="DE" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18224345" id="Pl-74" latLong="51.500°N 10.500°E" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Having a keen grasp of the obvious, she began a policy of acceding to Japanese hegemony in the area.
column2: Japanese PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-44" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Japan continued a policy of acquiring territory for some grand, illusive scheme of a "Greater Asia", subordinate and grateful to Japan .
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The reality of this was that only a single possession, Manchuria , was profitable to the Japanese, and the rest of the Empire turned out to be a drain.
column2: Japanese PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-44" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Manchuria PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18082116" id="Pl-76" latLong="49.600°N 117.433°E" type="PPL",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-49" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: This drain was greatly accelerated by Japan 's invasion of China proper in 1936.

column1: It was a war that Japan assumed would be ended in "3 to 6 months"; at the time of Pearl Harbor , it had been going on for 5 years, at the cost of over half a million Japanese lives.

column1: 29 Jan 2005 22:04:38 GMT The 1860 Presidential Election In 1860 there was a four-way race between the Republican Party with Abraham Lincold, the Democratic Party with Stephen Douglas, the Southern Democratic Party with John Breckenridge, and the Constitutional Union Party with John Bell.

column1: Got job?
And so, I have rejoined the world of the fully employed.
After Christmas, I got a call from the wife of one of my former bosses (at my last full-time job).
She was looking for a Development Assistant at the retirement community where she works.
I started here 4 weeks ago.
WM is affiliated with, but not run or fully supported by, the denomination I've been a part of all my life (UMC).
My grandmother (who was Baptist) lived here for a few months before she died in 1995, so I have many connections to the job.
Our offices are in one of the patio homes , and I have my own lovely office with a window.
The job's only about 12 miles from home , and I'm going against the bulk of the traffic mornings and afternoons.
It all seems perfect and yet.
.. yet..
. yet...

Oh, I'm so thankful to be somewhere so nice where I might actually make a difference in people's lives, and I want to keep an open mind and hope it'll last forever, but I have a feeling I'll be restless within a year or so.
My boss is a very nice person, but conservative and resistant to technology, i.e. computers, internet, etc.
We just got new computers a week and half ago, and she's griping about XP (her old OS was Windows 98--mine was 95, so I'm thrilled with the new stuff).
I tell her it'll just take some getting used to.
We'll see.
I'm not making the kind of salary I was hoping to get, but it's the best salary I've gotten thus far.
When I was fulltime in radio I made a little less, but I got quite a few remotes, which make up for not getting a topnotch salary.
I'm still doing my TV announcing and my weekend radio stuff, so that money will help.
I'm going to start actively pursuing more voice work in the next month or so, too.
My plan is to pay off my car early, and then work on the other debts.
I think it's time to go on and fill out the adoption applications.
I'm terrified of more debt, but Mom and Dad will help with the money.
I'm not sure they realize how expensive it all is.
I'm thinking we might lean toward adopting from Guatemala , but we've still not hashed it all out.
column2: ,Guatemala PLACE country="GT" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18864178" id="Pl-1" latLong="15.500°N 90.250°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: It's almost bad making some money now, because while most of me wants to save as much as possible, the other, smaller part is screaming loudly for stuff, stuff, stuff!!!
I've got a trial subscription to XM at work because of the Dell computers, and now I'm lusting to have it all of the time.
G got me a nice office stereo for my birthday and it does have an aux jack, so I could listen to it here.
He asked if I wanted a car stereo, and I said no, but I do.
There are so many things I want.
A garage .
A dining room set.
New stuff for our house . New clothes.
New everything.
But I want family more.
I think part of the draw of the other stuff is I could get it now.
But I'd be paying for it later.
Money makes the world go round and round and round til I'm just dizzy.

column1: EU backs stricter nuclear inspections in Iran
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-1" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Foreign ministers of the European Union (EU) said here Monday that they fully supported stricter nuclear inspections of Iran 's nuclear programs by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-7" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: A statement issued at the two-day meeting of the EU foreign ministers called on Iran to conclude and implement urgently and unconditionally an additional protocol to the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty allowing for short-notice inspections of suspected nuclear sites in the country.
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-7" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: It said that the EU was seriously concerned about Iran 's nuclear activities and urged it to cooperate fully with the IAEA.
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-7" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: This would be a significant step in demonstrating Iran 's stated peaceful intentions with regard to its nuclear program, the seven-point statement said.
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-7" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: George Papandreou, foreign minister of Greece , the current holder of the EU presidency, said he was in personal contact with IAEA Director-General Mohamed ElBaradei and would follow his lead on this matter.
column2: Greece PLACE country="GR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:20169939" id="Pl-9" latLong="39.000°N 22.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: EU foreign ministers reiterated that improved trade links with Iran should be conditional on Iran 's cooperation.
column2: Iran PLACE country="IR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16932748" id="Pl-7" latLong="32.000°N 53.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: China  to build nuclear-powered desalinator project
column2: China PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18099327" id="Pl-1" latLong="35.000°N 105.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: China late this year will start building a nuclear-powered desalinator project in Yantai City in east China 's Shandong Province , with a designed capacity of producing 52 million tons of fresh water a year.
column2: Yantai PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18064135" id="Pl-6" latLong="37.533°N 121.400°E" state="37" type="PPL",Shandong PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18075644" id="Pl-9" latLong="36.000°N 119.000°E" state="37" type="CIVIL",Shandong Province PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18075644" id="Pl-7" latLong="36.000°N 119.000°E" state="37" type="CIVIL",Yantai City PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18064135" id="Pl-5" latLong="37.533°N 121.400°E" state="37" type="PPL",China PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18099327" id="Pl-3" latLong="35.000°N 105.000°E" mod="E" type="COUNTRY",city PLACE country="CN" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:18064135" id="Pl-12" latLong="37.533°N 121.400°E" state="37" type="PPL"

column1: Officials with the Development Planning Commission of the Shandong provincial government said the project, to be built in cooperation with Qinghua University, would alleviate water shortages in the city and other parts of the Shandong Peninsula .
column2: Shandong PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18075644" id="Pl-9" latLong="36.000°N 119.000°E" state="37" type="CIVIL",Qinghua PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:26002097" id="Pl-13" latLong="36.682°N 114.291°E" state="11" type="PPL",Shandong Peninsula PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18075644" id="Pl-10" latLong="36.000°N 119.000°E" state="37" type="CIVIL",city PLACE country="CN" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:18064135" id="Pl-12" latLong="37.533°N 121.400°E" state="37" type="PPL"

column1: Yantai and other parts of Shandong suffered acute water shortages due to droughts in recent years, changing climate and other reasons.
column2: Yantai PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18064135" id="Pl-6" latLong="37.533°N 121.400°E" state="37" type="PPL",Shandong PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18075644" id="Pl-9" latLong="36.000°N 119.000°E" state="37" type="CIVIL"

column1: Approved by the State Development and Reform Commission, the project is expected to cost 1.6 billion yuan (nearly 200 million US dollars).
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Zhang Zuoyi, director of the Nuclear Energy Technology and Design Institute attached to Qinghua University, was quoted in Monday's Beijing Evening News as saying the fresh water to be produced from the project will cost 3.75 yuan per ton, much less than the cost of water from existing sources.
column2: Qinghua PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:26002097" id="Pl-13" latLong="36.682°N 114.291°E" state="11" type="PPL",Beijing PLACE country="CN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18101459" id="Pl-14" latLong="39.929°N 116.388°E" state="11" type="PPLC"

column1: US  donates money for Panama  's security forces
column2: Panama PLACE country="PA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19831979" id="Pl-9" latLong="9.000°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY",US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Panama is set to receive a donation of more than 7 million US dollars from the United States for the reinforcement of its security forces, local press reported Friday.
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-7" type="COUNTRY",Panama PLACE country="PA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19831979" id="Pl-13" latLong="9.000°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY",US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The US embassy in Panama handed over this week to the National Police 11 armored personnel vehicles, which could be used to transport security forces to reinforce security on the border with Colombia .
column2: Panama PLACE country="PA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19831979" id="Pl-13" latLong="9.000°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY",US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY",Colombia PLACE country="CO" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19418914" id="Pl-15" latLong="4.000°N 72.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Panamanian ambassador to Washington Roberto Alfaron said the donation, which has been approved by the US Congress, is a new step in the development of close relations between the two countries.
column2: Panama PLACE country="PA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19831979" id="Pl-13" latLong="9.000°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY",US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-4" type="COUNTRY",Washington PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:532871" id="Pl-16" latLong="38.895°N 77.037°W" state="DC" type="PPLC",Panamanian PLACE country="PA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19831979" id="Pl-12" latLong="9.000°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He said Panama is in a privileged position in relations with the United States after the signing of a bilateral agreement granting Americans immunity from the International Criminal Court (ICC).
column2: United States PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-7" type="COUNTRY",Panama PLACE country="PA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19831979" id="Pl-13" latLong="9.000°N 80.000°W" type="COUNTRY"
